msgSnippet: Thank you for your detailed explanation. I have added to the excluded.properties file this line: excluded.6=org.w3c.* and it works now with and without class

Thank you for your detailed explanation. I have added to the
excluded.properties file this line:

excluded.6=org.w3c.*

and it works now with and without class reloading. Anyway, I will check the
recommended readings.

Diego


----- Original Message -----
From: "Scott Stirling" <sstirling@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, July 19, 2001 8:00 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] SwingUI and AWTUI don't work with PROJECTX?


Again, this problem is due to TestCaseClassloader. You're right about the
solution.

This particular exception is even more puzzling than the oft-encountered
LinkageError because you get it even though you probably didn't change any
of the classes that supposedly changed, right?  IncompatibleClassChangeError
is a subclass of LinkageError.

The JVM is fooled by the defining loader part of the class's type (every
runtime class type = fullyQualifiedClassname;definingLoaderInstance) into
"assuming" that com.sun.xml.tree.XmlDocument, which would have been loaded
by the JVM's system class loader due to the default excluded.properties,
does not implement org.w3c.dom.Document, which would have been loaded by
JUnit's class loader, also due to the default excluded.properties.  Well of
course it does -- at compile time!  But at runtime the "types" of the two
classes are defined by their name plus their defining classloader's
instance, so the JVM doesn't see them as meeting the required contract.

This is the third significant problem we've seen caused by the combination
of XML classes and the default exclusion list in JUnit's custom class
loader: LinkageErrors and this IncompatibleClassChangeError revolving around
JAXP and other Sun XML classes that depend on org.w3c and org.xml.sax
classes, and ClassCastExceptions with EJB home object stubs.  I've written
explanations for all three of them in the past two weeks (see recent list
archives if you care).  They all share the same root cause.

For a great explanation of the underlying issues with Java 2 classloaders
and loader constraints, see

"Dynamic Class Loading in the Java Virtual Machine"
by Sheng Liang and Gilad Bracha
Presented at OOPSLA'98, October 20-22, Vencouver, Canada.
http://java.sun.com/people/sl/

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Diego Parrilla Santamar�a [mailto:diegoparrilla@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, July 19, 2000 1:41 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] SwingUI and AWTUI don't work with PROJECTX?
>
>
> I tried to bootstrap the XML package, but still it doesn't work.
>
> I have been trying with different options, and when "Reload
> classes every
> run"  is unchecked, it works. I've been reading some stuff at
> Sourceforge,
> and it seems that the problem is something to do with the
> "junit\runner\excluded.properties" file. I have not tested
> yet, but may be I
> have to exclude org.w3c.* and org.xml.* in order to do it
> work properly.
>
> I will let you know about this.
>
> Diego
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Thursday, July 19, 2001 3:26 PM
> Subject: RE: [junit] SwingUI and AWTUI don't work with PROJECTX?
>
>
> This sounds like the problem we were getting with some CORBA
> applications.
> We needed to bootstrap our CORBA packages before the rt.jar.
>
> Try this --
> java Xbootclasspath:<your DOM jar>;rt.jar
>
> note: if you are in UNIX the separator should be a colon, not
> a semicolon.
>
> Let us know if that works.
>
> -Jason
>
>     > -----Original Message-----
>     > From: Diego Parrilla Santamar�a [mailto:diegoparrilla@...]
>     > Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 7:01 PM
>     > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>     > Subject: [junit] SwingUI and AWTUI don't work with PROJECTX?
>     >
>     >
>     > Hello everybody,
>     >
>     > I'm using the JUnit framework to test an application that
>     > uses the factory
>     > of DOM trees of the PROJECTX (The SUN implementation of
>     > DOM) libraries.
>     > Everything was great while I was using the text only
>     > interface of JUnit.
>     > Then, I decided to move to the SWING interface, but then
>     > the application
>     > stopped working. I tried with AWT interface, and I
>     > obtained the same error.
>     > This error is:
>     >
>     > java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError: class
>     > com.sun.xml.tree.XmlDocument
>     > does not implement interface org.w3c.dom.Document
>     >  at optica.api.bd.QueryToXML.buildXML(QueryToXML.java:215)
>     >  at optica.api.bd.QueryToXML.execute(QueryToXML.java:45)
>     >  at
> optica.api.bd.TransformNames.execute(TransformNames.java:103)
>     >  at
>     > optica.api.bd.QueryToXMLTest.testConexionBBDD(QueryToXMLTe
>     > st.java:108)
>     >
>     > and the line 215 is:
>     >
>     >        Element rowset = doc.createElement(aRowSet);
>     >
>     > doc is a DOM Document, and aRowSet is a String.
>     >
>     > Then I decided to change the PROJECTX libraries for the
>     > XML4J from IBM. And
>     > it works!!!
>     >
>     > The questions are: Why can I run this test in text mode ?
>     > Why can't I use
>     > the PROJECTX libraries with the graphical interface of Junit ?
>     >
>     > Any help will be welcomed.
>     > Bye
>     >
>     > Diego Parrilla
>     >
>     > P.D.: Excuse me for my high-school english.
